I am a PhD candidate in Statistics at Oregon State University. I am currently a Software Engineer Intern at Posit Software, PBC (formerly RStudio, Inc).
Outside of work, I enjoy skiing, traveling, being outdoors, and watching thriller or dark comedy films and series on Netflix.

title: Dev, data, deploy ‚Äî summer vibes, Posit style
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è work-in-progress
This summer, I worked at Posit (formerly RStudio), focusing on machine learning and software development as part of the tidymodels team. I primarily worked on {filtro}, an R package for filter-based supervised feature selection.
My team at tidymodels is responsible for the creation and maintenance of the {tidymodels} 1 framework, a collection of R packages for modeling and machine learning. It is similar in scope and purpose to {scikit-learn} in Python.

title: Experience
text:
Oregon State University

Doctoral Researcher
Sep 2021 - Present


Statistics / ML Consultant
Jan 2021 - Mar 2025
‚Ä¢ Provided consulting services across diverse fields, collaborating with faculty members, junior statisticians, and client researchers to support multiple PhD and master‚Äôs-level research initiatives.  ‚Ä¢ Effectively communicated statistical concepts to non-statistical clients and delivered in-depth reports on topics including simple statistical tests, advanced data modeling, application software (R, Python), experimental design, and data processing and visualization.


Graduate Teaching Assistant
Mar 2020 - Present
‚Ä¢ Assist with graduate and undergraduate courses such as machine learning III, missing data and causal inference, spatial statistics, stochastic models, computational statistics, data analysis methods I (hypothesis testing, multiple testing), II (regression analysis, model selection), III (dimension reduction techniques, generalized regression models), mathematical statistics I, II, statistical methods, statistics for engineers, and elementary statistics I.  ‚Ä¢ Teach R programming and discuss statistical problems during labs or recitations, hold office hours, and grade exams and assignments.


Graduate Project Assistant
Jun 2024 - Aug 2024
‚Ä¢ Assisted with the design and development of the course curriculum for spatial statistics.  ‚Ä¢ Applied a variety of spatial models, including kriging / Gaussian process regression, C / SAR (conditional / simultaneous autoregressive), and Poisson process / CSR models for simulation and applications such as housing price prediction, disease risk mapping, and forest and forest fire modeling.

title: About
text:
Thanks for visiting my site!
I am a PhD candidate in Statistics at Oregon State University. Broadly speaking, my research interests lie in
for large and complex time series data, with applications to energy forecasting and claims prediction. My other interests include deep learning and its more flexible and explainable probabilistic variant models (e.g., deep Gaussian processes, deep Gaussian Markov Random Fields) for space and space-time modeling.

title: Portfolio
text: No matching items

title: About
text:
PhD
For my PhD dissertation, advised by Dr.¬†Lisa Madsen and Dr.¬†Charlotte Wickham (now at Posit Software, PBC), I focus on the Markov MTD (Mixture Transition Distribution) models and the Bayesian NNMP (Nearest-Neighbor Mixture Process) models for time series forecasting and spatial prediction, as developed by Zheng et al.¬†and presented in [1], [2], and [3]. To achieve flexible and scalable modeling of time series and spatial data, both the MTD and NNMP models utilize probabilistic graphical model (DAG or Bayesian network) representations, finite mixture model structures, Bayesian hierarchical model formations, and MCMC algorithms.
My specific contributions include incorporating the copulas in the MTD model to capture more complex dependence structures; extending the MTD model to handle zero-inflated positively-skewed data; validating the proposed models and assessing model performance through simulations and real-world data applications; developing a software package for the proposed models (using R, C++); and comparing the proposed models with other benchmark approaches, such as LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks (using PyTorch).

title: About
text:
Master‚Äôs
For my Master‚Äôs capstone project, advised by Dr.¬†James Molyneux, I worked on selected spatial and temporal point processes leading up to Hawkes processes (or self-exciting point processes), which find applications in fields such as seismology, criminology, risk management, finance, etc.

title: Dev, data, deploy ‚Äî summer vibes, Posit style
text:
The Journey So Far

filtro

As mentioned earlier, I primarily worked on {filtro}, an R package for filter-based supervised feature selection. Feature selection is important because it helps models prioritize the most relevant information, reducing noise, speeding up computation, and improving performance and interpretability.
At its core, the package allows users to compute and rank feature relevance, then select the most important features based on these scores. It also supports multiparameter optimization, enabling users to optimize multiple scores at once. If you want to learn more about {filtro}, check it out here.


tidymodels
{tidymodels} supports the full modeling workflow, from preprocessing and optimization to evaluation, postprocessing, and prediction. {filtro} fits into the preprocessing and optimization step. It is just one of several packages available, with others complementing different steps of the workflow.
But, why {tidymodels} instead of {scikit-learn}? If you want Python‚Äôs flexibility and a vast ML ecosystem, {scikit-learn} is an excellent choice. But if you prefer R‚Äôs syntax, value structured modeling workflows, and appreciate tools designed by statisticians and data scientists who were setting best practices long before ‚Äúmachine learning‚Äù became a buzzword, {tidymodels} may be the better fit. If you want to learn more about {tidymodels}, check it out here.

In a rush? Jump to the End.


Still reading? Stay for Behind the Scenes.

title: A Great Summer of Dev, Data, and Deploy at Posit
text:
Behind the Curtain

PR #1: All the Things, All at Once
Week 1-2
My first few weeks at Posit were packed with learning and collaboration. I had daily meetings with Max and Emil. Max brings deep expertise in modeling,machine learning and software design, while Emil is highly knowledgeable about software development, from Git, GitHub Actions CI/CD (nasty stuff!) to Positron (a VS Code‚Äìlike IDE), and R‚Äôs S3 object-oriented programming (OOP) 2.
It‚Äôs tempting to jump straight into coding and testing, but Max taught an important lesson: before writing any code, it‚Äôs crucial to step back and think through the software design ‚Äî often, the real challenge lies in the methodology, not just the implementation. Meanwhile, Emil and I did some pair programming, which led to two great learning sessions:

‚ÄúEverything Positron‚Äù 3 
‚ÄúEverything S3 OOP‚Äù.



S3 OOP Brush-Up
Week 1-4
To be completely honest, while Xiaotian‚Äôs {mtd} 4 package is quite well-organized ‚Äî and I would argue that the most challenging aspect of extending it lies more in model development than in software engineering, I had little to no experience with R‚Äôs S3 OOP system. So here I am, pretty much glued to the Advanced R and R Packages books and poking around the {tune} package (plus {yardstick} and a few others) through weeks 1 to 4 to level up my S3 OOP game.


A Turning Point
Week 5
Max, Hadley, and I met to discuss the API design for the {desirability2} package. During the discussion, Hadley demonstrated some code using S7 5 and recommended incorporating it. üò± (That‚Äôs the ‚Äúface screaming in fear‚Äù emoji because I am both thrilled and frightened ‚Äî thrilled to meet him, but nervous about living up to expectations!)
To cap off an exciting week, Emil and I prepared and submitted {filtro} to CRAN 6.


CRAN Horror Story to Acceptance and Dual Branches
Week 6
I had to resubmit the package after making a few reasonable but minimal errors. Following the resubmission, the reviewer emailed me asking for revisions, with no further details. Gathering my courage, I replied back for clarification, and shortly after received an apology along with the great news that {filtro} is now on CRAN. üöÄ
The S3 branch was now on CRAN, while the S7 branch lived on as the development version ‚Äî many branches ahead in features and updates. In practice, though, I was juggling multiple branches, as I got used to merging, resolving conflicts, and navigating real-world Git and GitHub workflows, though I still find CI/CD concepts a bit abstract and challenging.


The Great S7 Migration
Week 5-8

Implement S7 for all scoring methods
Write S7 tests for all scoring methods
Refactor code using S7 (Max led the way!)
Refactor tests accordingly



Write, Write, and Write‚Ä¶
Week 9

Write, write, and write, (but not the dissertation kind!)

Though the internship was entirely remote, I had the pleasure of meeting the other intern, Jules, as well as other developers based in Europe and across the US. The most fun, though initially intimidating, experience was the tidyteam meeting, where the tidyverse, tidymodels, and r-lib 7 teams all gathered on Zoom once a month. It felt like seeing all the key people at Posit all at once 8.

title: Dev, data, deploy ‚Äî summer vibes, Posit style
text:
Onward & Upward
As of August 15, 2025, I have two weeks left in my internship, but there‚Äôs still quite a bit left to do:
For {filter}:

Refining documentation and writing a tidymodels developer post
Updating the CRAN version to match the development version

For {important} 9:

Working with Max and Emil to develop the receipt steps

And of course:

Finalizing this very post about my internship üòÄ

I look forward to wrapping up these projects and seeing them contribute to the broader tidymodels ecosystem.
A big thank you to everyone at Posit for an invaluable experience, and special thanks to Max, Emil, Hannah, Simon, and Hadley for their guidance, support, and inspiration throughout this journey.

I want to thank my co-advisor, Charlotte, for encouraging me to write and organize my dissertation using Positron. But, it wasn‚Äôt until this internship that I unlocked its full potential for software development and Git integration, though it was also Charlotte who helped me get this internship. ü§©‚Ü©Ô∏é
This is the package I build upon in my PhD dissertation. See Xiaotian‚Äôs package at https://github.com/xzheng42/mtd. My extended version will be available on GitHub in late December or later. ü§û‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: Dev, data, deploy ‚Äî summer vibes, Posit style
text:
Behind the Scenes

PR #1: All the Things, All at Once
My first 2 weeks at Posit were packed with learning and collaboration. Max brings deep expertise in modeling, machine learning and software design, and Emil is highly knowledgeable about software development, from Positron (a VS Code‚Äìlike IDE) and R‚Äôs S3 object-oriented programming (OOP), to Posit‚Äôs developer tools, Git and GitHub Actions CI/CD. I later realized that Hannah excels at PRs, unit tests, and software design best practices, and I learned a lot from her as well!
One important lesson from Max is that, while it is tempting to jump straight into coding, it‚Äôs far more important to step back and think through the software design ‚Äî often, the real challenge lies in the methodology, not the implementation. Meanwhile, Emil and I did some pair programming, which led to two valuable learning sessions from him:

‚ÄúEverything Positron‚Äù (Thanks to my advisor Charlotte for already giving me a brief intro! 3) 
‚ÄúEverything S3 OOP‚Äù.



S3 OOP Brush-Up
Prior to this internship, I had little to no prior experience with R‚Äôs S3 OOP system. This is because while Xiaotian‚Äôs {mtd} 4 package is quite well-organized, it makes minimal use of OOP ‚Äî though I would argue in defense that the most challenging aspect of extending {mtd} lies more in model development than in software engineering.
So here I am, pretty much glued to the Advanced R by Hadley and R Packages books by Hadley and Jenny, while poking around {dials}, {yardstick}, {tune} and a few other packages through weeks 1 to 4 to level up my S3 OOP game.


A Turning Point
Week 5 began with a meeting between Max and Hadley to discuss the API design for the {desirability2} package, the package that powers {filtro} for multiparameter optimization. During the discussion, Hadley demonstrated some code using S7 5 and suggested incorporating it. üò± At the time, it felt like a daunting task, and I was both thrilled and frightened ‚Äî thrilled to meet him, yet nervous about living up to expectations!
To cap off an exciting week, Emil and I prepared and submitted {filtro} 6 to CRAN 7.


CRAN Horror Story to Acceptance and Dual Branches
After resubmitting for minor errors, the reviewer sent a vague revision request with no details, leaving me in the dark 8. Following advice from Max and Emil, I replied back for clarification, and shortly after received an apology along with the great news that {filtro} is now on CRAN. üöÄ
The S3 branch was now on CRAN, while the S7 branch lived on as the development version, with many branches ahead in features and updates. In practice, though, I was juggling multiple branches, as I got used to merging, resolving conflicts, and navigating real-world Git and GitHub workflows, though I still find CI/CD concepts a bit abstract and challenging.


The Great S7 Migration üõ•
Since meeting with Hadley in week 5, my weeks 5 to 8 were largely focused on implementing S7 for all scoring methods. I also spent a lot of time rewriting tests to match the new setup and helping with code refactoring, while Max laid the groundwork with 1-2 methods.
These four weeks were the most challenging yet rewarding part of my internship. I had the opportunity to work closely with Max. I learned a lot just by observing how he approached problems, structured code, and made decisions during refactoring. It was a steep learning curve, but I grew a lot ‚Äî from writing cleaner, more maintable code to thinking more critically about software design and user experience.


Write, Write, and Write‚Ä¶
From week 9 onward, it‚Äôs all about writing, and thankfully, not the dissertation kind. The vignette pages for all other tidy pages are phenomenal: clear, concise, and accessible. That sets the tone and adds a bit of pressure to deliver my best.
It also feels like just a blink from developing, refactoring, and deploying the package to now writing documentation, demos, and tutorials. But at the very least, the package website for {filtro} is up running!

title: Dev, data, deploy ‚Äî summer vibes, Posit style
section: The Perks of Being a Posit Intern
text:
The Perks of Being a Posit Intern
Though the internship was entirely remote, I had the pleasure of meeting Jules, the other intern on the Python team, as well as engineers based in Europe and across the U.S. They were all very friendly and generous with tips and guidance.
The most exciting though initially intimidating experience was the monthly tidyteam meeting, where the tidyverse, tidymodels, and r-lib 2 teams all gathered on Zoom once a month. It felt like seeing all the idols at Posit all at once!
I also enjoyed the weekly tidymodels meetings with Max, Emil, Hannah, and Simon. The depth of the team‚Äôs many packages could be a lot to absorb at times, but it offered a glimpse into collaborative software development, the challenges of managing a large ecosystem, and effective communication in open-source environment. Plus, Simon‚Äôs work on AI assistance through LLM integration (RAG) was always refreshing to hear.

section: The Perks of Being a Posit Intern
text:
The Perks of Being a Posit Intern
Though the internship was entirely remote, I had the pleasure of meeting Jules, the other intern on the Python open-source team, as well as engineers based in Europe and across the U.S. They were all very friendly and generous with tips and guidance.
The most exciting though initially intimidating experience was the monthly tidyteam meeting, where the tidyverse, tidymodels, and r-lib 3 teams all gathered on Zoom once a month. It felt like seeing all the idols at Posit all at once!
I also enjoyed the weekly tidymodels meetings with Max, Emil, Hannah, and Simon. The depth of the team‚Äôs many packages could be a lot to absorb at times, but it offered a glimpse into collaborative software development, the challenges of managing a large ecosystem, and effective communication in open-source environment. Plus, Simon‚Äôs work on AI assistance through LLM integration (RAG) was always refreshing to hear.

title: Dev, data, deploy ‚Äî summer vibes, Posit style
text:
The Journey So Far

filtro

As mentioned earlier, I primarily worked on {filtro}, an R package for filter-based supervised feature selection. Feature selection is important because it helps models prioritize the most relevant information, reducing noise, speeding up computation, and improving performance and interpretability.
At its core, the package allows users to compute and rank feature relevance, then select the most important features based on these scores. It also supports multiparameter optimization, enabling users to optimize multiple scores at once. If you want to learn more about {filtro}, check it out here.


tidymodels
{tidymodels} supports the full modeling workflow, from preprocessing and optimization to evaluation, postprocessing, and prediction. {filtro} fits into the preprocessing and optimization step. It is just one of several packages available, with others complementing different steps of the workflow.
But, why {tidymodels} instead of {scikit-learn}? I‚Äôve found myself drawn to {scikit-learn} because of Python‚Äôs vast machine learning ecosystem, and since I already work with {pytorch}. At the same time, I really appreciate {tidymodels} when I‚Äôm working in R. Its syntax feels natural, the workflows are well-structured, and it reflects the kind of statistical rigor and thoughtful design that statisticians and data scientists had been shaping long before ‚Äúmachine learning‚Äù became a buzzword. If you want to learn more about {tidymodels}, check it out here.

In a rush? Jump to the End.

As I write this, I have two weeks left in my internship, but there‚Äôs still quite a bit left to do:

Thanks for reading this, and happy to connect!
